subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On PALM
msgSnippet: ... Read went with Choice 2 for SQUARE, so if we interpret his spelling of mere as Choice 1 for NEAR, then it means these choices (and that for CURE) are not
messageBody:
On Nov 20, 2007 8:37 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
>
>
> > merry Ed Roar (er)
> > Mary Age Roar (Er)
> > marry Ash Roar (Ar)
>
> These are different from the others because the /r/ is in the following
> syllable, which is why even non-rhotics pronounce it.
>
> > mire Ice Roar (Fr)
>
> This is two syllables also, but the /r/ is the NURSE vowel, so I'd write
> it I-Utter-Roe. Read (an RP speaker) probably can't hear the distinction
> between this word and the words listed below.
>
>
> > mar Ah Roar (yR)
> > more Awl Roar (Yr)
> > mere If Roar (ir)
> > murder Ado Roar (ar)
>
> These are the true vowel+r combinations that should (and do) have
> ligatures. Read doesn't tell us about "mare" and "moor", but the fact that
> he spells "mere" with It says he favors what we've been calling Choice 1.
> I don't think that's necessarily definitive, though.

Read went with Choice 2 for SQUARE, so if we interpret his spelling of
"mere" as Choice 1 for NEAR, then it means these choices (and that for
CURE) are not necessarily so tightly coupled.

Ted


> (Note that "more" actually belongs to FORCE, so for people who separate
> it from NORTH it would be spelled with Owe-Roe instead of Awe-Roe.
> There is no NORTH word beginning with /m/, but "or" or "for" would do.)
>
> --
> John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
> If I have seen farther than others, it is because I am surrounded by
> dwarves.
> --Murray Gell-Mann
>
>
